comments.text: I'm currently on 3080 and 3440x1440. I've been enticed by the uplift here or there, but stupid me paid the virus tax for my 3080 and I have to take that into consideration. Not enough to justify the real world cost for me, given my nearly double msrp blunder for the 3080. I've been watching gpu/pc related hardware reviews for a few years now and I'm grateful that the reviewers are experiencing (and voicing) the same frustrations we as consumers have. "The rent is too damn high". Thanks Jay and team for another down to earth review, keep doing what you do and making great content.

comments.text: Here is the thing. The RTX 5080 is all about options. For example, many benchmarks show the RTX 5080 barely above other cards but they are not taking into consideration multi-frame gen (MFG). Testing 3x frame gen there is hardly any input lag at all and it will beat a 4090 in anything at that point, using less power....kinda neat. And if I don't need the extra frames above 60 fps, then I will lower the MFG to X2 or off entirely. I just like how many options the card gives you using software. I DONT agree with their insane anti-consumer speech and prices however. Now IF they bring their multi frame gen to the 4000 series cards well then that will be interesting haha but I dont think they will.

comments.text:
Multi frame gen in reality works like this.
The people who need frames  (cheaper cards), cannot get them without increased negative consequences..

The people who don’t really need more frames  (5090), see the least negative impact for turning on multiframe generation.

The idea that was sold is that you can get a 5070 at a decent price point and get 4090 performance. That’s just outright not true.  If you are running 20 FPS in a game, they are going to be a lot of negative consequences using multiframe generation to get up to 120 frames.

The fewer frames you start with before you turn on such a feature, the more input lag, the more artifacting, the more blurring, and the funny thing is, you probably bought a 4K monitor so you could see things in high definition.

That’s why I say 1440 P is still the sweet spot , unless you’re one of the one percent of people who will eventually have the 5090 and it’s not going to break the bank

comments.text:
Not even that. Personally I run LLMs locally but my 3070 Ti struggles big time on a 30B model (obviously), and I'm kind of interested to experiment games using LLMs. Thing is, even 16 Gb of VRAM is pretty low. There are people running crypto mining like rigs with two RTX 3090 if not more just for that application because that yields enough VRAM to not have to offload on other ocmponents (RAM and CPU) which are making LLMs run utterly slow otherwise. That's precisely why Nvidia is putting all the VRAM chips to their more expensive server cluster cards (A100 and H100). This is why those cloud LLMs yield instantaneous responses on trillions of parameters in a way.

If these cards are good "AI" cards then I'm the Emperor of Antartica. They are giving you barely "good enough" specs with 16 Gb.

I really don't mind the general price increase in hardware as much as most people seem. Inflation is a thing, the more complicated manufacturing ramps up costs, I get all that.

comments.text: 3:31 I'd say its less of a process node shortcoming and more of an architectural one. comments.text:
When we are just swapping out computation power that is relevant , for something less relevant in the use case (swapping graphics computation for AI computation)- it plain stupid to me. Something like going for a limited data approach makes sense maybe in online real time gaming - where your data will always be limited by distance and be delayed. On a graphics card, when you choose a lesser data basis, to then compute with another circuitry some guesses, it makes absolutely no sense, because you couldve just spend the space on computation for the raw data instead, thus never needing the creativity. 

The fundamental use case assumes you have performance issues, which should be hopefully rare with a 5090. It makes zero sense in a case where you have good frametimes already. 

Sure it will be more flexible because of AI's lot less restrictive pipeline. But it is a graphics card so I dont know who really asked for flexibility in that sense. The only downside to the computation circuitry of the classic pipeline is that it is mostly suited to do .... graphics. Which is a small problem when you are a graphics card..........  

It is really 99% hype from jensen. He creates problems and then provides you the solution. As with raytracing. Suddenly nvidia pushes to go beyond our capabilities in terms of compute power for ray tracing - to then present cards with dedicated ray tracing circuitry. Its so disingenuous. Why go and insist on some immature technology with insane demands(RT) , that even needs purpose build circuitry to keep up because of the massively inefficient computations. People forget that it is a choice, and historically we never chose to insist on raw ray tracing because............ its stupid expensive until someone comes up with another genius idea to simplify the calculations even more. 

The dude is basically doing whatever he can to make you the most dependant on him for future hardware. Its stupid, and everybody paying premium right now to consolidate the power of this maniac is honestly not very bright.
comments.author: @jonaswox

comments.text: Considering there has been very little difference between the last few generations in terms of real performance I'm not surprised you are underwhelmed. Everyone talks about benchmarking but you don't notice a difference when you are actually gaming. The hardware has long since surpassed the software's ability to utilize the hardware. CPU's are suffering from this on a far greater scale in gaming since very few games, if any, are coded to use more than one core or even need more than one. The average desktop PC is the equivalent of a super computer in the mid to late 90's and we are busy playing games on them. The average smart phone has enough computing power to run 6 space shuttles simultaneously, and we are using them to play candy crush.

comments.text: Any testing of cards should be ONLY native resolution and native frames. Upscaling or framegen are ways to get more frames displayed instead of dropping quality of graphics. Same for specs on a game purchase: just display native requirements. If someone wants more frames, then they can fiddle the render quality down or upscale or generate interpolations as they deem fit. Now how good the game is at USING upscaling or framegen COMPARED TO NATIVE to get at, above, or below native quality output is a thing, and the better a game is at getting there with either AMD or NVidia tech doing it is a thing, but it is a game thing, not overall, unless that is ALL you are doing (comparing an average "this is near enough native quality visuals" for each tech, AMD, AMD hardware acc, Intel or NVidia). Just eschew all the software to ape more frames when you are testing the card for review OF THE CARD. After all, they can decide to bring out a DLSS4.5 at any time they want, etc. so the CARD doesn't change, and it is the CARD that you are reviewing, not the software stack and not the games implementation for that software.

comments.text:
The thing that every reviewer has failed to even consider is that we have been dealing with some of the highest inflation in recent American history since way back in the 1970's when Jimmy Carter was ruining the economy and everyone was driving very old rusting cars and the public was completely fine with that. Nobody could afford anything nice.

The problem is not the 5080. The problem was the 4080, over compensation for a too low price on the 3080. So, it would seem to me that as chart-loving people, you guys really dropped the ball on this one. The 5080 is a VERY, VERY GOOD DEAL. Much better than the 4080.

Maybe, it's just easier to hate. To have an emotional response and just be angry. Or disappointed. Or otherwise unhappy. It's probably just easier. It probably even makes more money because who wants to click on a title that says, "Nvidia released a card with a reasonable price" vs "NVIDIA = Evil, Greedy, DO NOT BUY & I TELL YOU WHY!!!!!!"

It's just not a very good representation of reality. The card is priced better than the 4080 and reasonably across all previous cards when considering the reality of all companies being beholden to stock holders. The price must go up. Inflation demands it. Capitalism demands it. And probably purchasers demand it. I know that I often will select "Price High-to-Low" whenever I'm thinking about buying anything at all anywhere. There is an automatic belief-system that regardless of truth dictates that people will be more likely to believe a product is better simply because it is priced higher.

At any rate, I'm not happy with the reviewers for bashing the pricing of a card that costs HALF of the next higher card. I think it is disconnected with reality.
comments.author: @TJM-2023

comments.text: So I want to see how this plays out.  4000 series: 4090 was close to 2x the performance of the 3090.  The 4060 was roughly equal to the 3060 performance, until you got a game that needed more the the 4060's 8GB of VRAM, then the 3060 beat it.  5000 series: 5090 is about 33% more performance than the 4090.  The 5080 is roughly 14% more performance than the 4080.  I want to know if this keeps going,  down to the point where the 5060 is roughly equal in performance to the 4060/3060 again.  Basically, the average gamer getting the shaft, while the higher tiers get all the uplift.  Too soon to tell, at this point, but we'll see!  In my opinion, if the 5090 got a 33% bump from the 4090, all the tiers should end up with that approximate 33% bump, not scale down to virtually nothing.  It thought the same thing when the 4000 series came out and the 4090 go all the bump and the 4060 got almost none, while also being neutered with only 8GB of VRAM compared to its predecessor's 12GB.

NEW 7900XTX ( “Hellhound” and other mid-high end cooler models at Micro Center) for $849 to $999 is a great value compared to this card. It will probably peform similarly but despite being G6 and not G7 the XTX has about a similar transistor count and a larger die with 24GB at a 384bit bus. I have a Nitro + Vapor chamber X model and it hits up to 500W peak board power, temps of hotspot seem to be in low 70s most of time. Quad slot. Yet i just had to go to Microcenter and I see three dozen people camping for 48hrs in the cold to buy what appears to be 5 skus of 5080 and ZERO 5090s listed as “available on 1/30” so these ppl are freezing their nuts off to pay $1299 for a 5080 which is a MASSIVE cut down physical die relative to the AD102, GB102, and Navi 31 XT….. Its depressing to see, I wanted to try to spark up a convo with them and be like “yooo yk the XTXs they got for $849 to $1149 (absolutely insane top end quad slot cooler model) is a significantly better price/perf ratio… 

i dont shill AMD. I think their mobile line is intentionally as confusing as possible to try to make cores as old as zen 2 and vega igpu cores sound as recent as new silicon within the past two years, not like 6-8yrs  ago

comments.text:
I have five 3090s from the mining craze. SOOOO glad that I picked the 3090s over the 3080s when I bought them, even thought they were RIDICULOUSLY overpriced, during the height of the mining craze, but I also always saw it as an "investment" in the sense that I won't need to upgrade for a really LOOONNGGGGG time.

And whilst yes, the 5080 WOULD be an upgrade over my 3090, but without the 24 GB of VRAM, I can use two 3090s to get a combined total of 48 GB of VRAM for LLMs, whereas I would need three 5080s to accomplish the same.

So there's more than just the straight performance piece to this puzzle. IF the 5080 had 24 GB of VRAM, then it would be worth considering.

Without it, the data and the evidence shows that my 3090s is still perfectly fine.

Besides, my eyes are so poor anyways that when I am playing Halo Infinite, I can't even see the eye candy anyways.

I think that's where a lot of reviews also fall short is that they will look for something specific, but not when you're trying to jump around to kill someone else before they kill you.

Would you even NOTICE the eye candy then when your objective, at that moment in time, is to not die?

comments.text:
Jay, it's clear what Nvidia has changed on the cooler. Aside from not using liquid metal and using normal thermal paste, the cooler looks identical but it definitely no longer has a vapor chamber internally. Which explains the 200g lower weight. This means that there is no longer any evaporation in the pipes on the outside, but rather, as with other GPU/CPU coolers, there are "only" simple heat pipes that transport the heat to the outside and the fans cool the fins around them. Which is why the fans rotate almost as fast (and are therefore as loud even though you would expect the 5080 to be much quieter due to the lower TDP...!) as those on the 5090. The 5080FE is therefore a much worse design than its board partners, who will simply continue to use the coolers from the 4080 and will also be much cooler = quieter thanks to the much larger cooler surface. If Nvidia had just dispensed with the liquid metal but kept the vapor chamber, everything would have been fine for the 2-slot design. So this time the FE is only recommended for people who have the tower under the table or who only play with headphones...

PS: "Der 8auer" had massive problems getting the 5080FE to work on his bench table as long as he had PCIe 5.0 active in the BIOS. And that despite NOT using a separate riser cable! Only changing from Automatic/PCIe5.0 to PCI 4.0 in the BIOS of the mainboard allowed the PC to start without any problems with the 5080FE. Which means that the start-up problems that others had with the 5090FE (because of the riser cable already installed internally by nvidia so that this 2-slot "blow trough" cooler works), he had with the 5080FE.

So even without using a riser cable in your tower, it's a bit like Russian roulette as to whether the 5080/5090FE will start with the default setting in the BIOS, which is always set to "Automatic", or whether it will be STABLE in Windows or games later. In other words, the problem will fill many forums in the coming weeks...where laypeople will complain about problems because they think their new 5080/5090FE is broken...

comments.text:
You really can tell how many folks in the comment have become "conditioned" to an every generation upgrade being the norm because of the 3K vs 4K series.

Been building since 2000.  Not a single time have I upgraded 1 generation, 2-3 generations always has been and still is perfectly fine.  And yes my EVGA 2080 is still playing everything I need it to and telling me it's time to upgrade again.

The real people creating these price issues are those jumping generation to generation and thinking that is normal.  Anybody with a 4080 or 4080 super even looking at a 5080 is simply doing it wrong.  We ALL KNOW the 5080 super/ti will be coming, anybody without FOMO and some self control can easily wait things out a bit and see how this all shakes out.

I set my systems up for 5ish years of quality gaming, not 5ish years of OMG max everything to keep throwing money at the machine.

Now if we don't get a 5080 super/ti with a VRAM uplift, then we have cause for concern as it won't be as future proof as it needs to be for the typical 5 year replacement cycle.

comments.text: I am not a fan boy, but after spending 5+ minutes saying the RTX 5080 is underwhelming, the video then shows more compelling ray tracing results.  Surely Nivida thinks gamers want ray tracing, and are willing to pay for it, or a lot of them would buy AMD?  Then they go onto talk about MFG.  Then they say the tech is impressive ( with a caveat.)  Ok, we (people who have been following 5xxx,) there's an input latency hit.  Not good for first person shooters, but some of us don't play first person shooters.  I am not saying the review is wrong.  But it sure seems like there's a bandwagon of reviewers bagging on Nvida.  I can understand that, as people do portray them as Big Evil Corp (tm.)  But for those of us who have followed hardware reviews for decades, this is how it works.  Either there's some new tech jump, like the loved 3xxx series, or it's just a refresh.  For people wanting to upgrade from the RTX 4xxx, well then, probably no, unless you have the cash to upgrade every few years spending 1000+ each time now.  But for people on say 5 year old GPUs, don't they just want to know price vs performance in their price category?
comments.author: @michaelbauers8800

comments.text: Then you read all the posts here.  More bandwagon thinking.  Crap they say.  A crime they say.  Again, these comments make some sense, if the goal is every 2 years or so, to always blow people's socks off.  But that NEVER happens right?  Some iterations will always be more impressive.  Long story short, and IMO, it's about CURRENT price vs performance for a lot of buyers, only some people are looking to upgrade every 2 years.  How many are those, percentage-wise?  Or do the hardware channels think only the PC hardware geeks care about reviews?  Hey, if Nvidia fails to impress in some iteration interval, and AMD blows people's mind, just vote with your wallet.  But AMDs best is the XTX, and while it's great as raster, not so great at RT.  Purchase based on your eval of price vs performance vs features.  And  ignore the emotional words designed to generate views or something.

comments.text:
As someone who's looking to upgrade from a PC that's over a decade old at this point, all I'm really worried about is the idea that the 5080 might struggle with some AI stuff. AI is still VERY new to me, when chat-gpt blew up I intentionally didn't use it, nor did I pay much attention to the progress of the technology beyond seeing a cool or funny implementation of it on YouTube every now and then. But I've had an opportunity to dip my toes into the subject recently and I'm definitely curious to explore the potential of this technology.

Obviously I'm not going to get a 5090. For someone like me, 2k for a graphics card alone is like paying for a new car by selling everything you own, only to not have anything left over for gas. (unless you're filthy rich)
No point in a new PC if said PC has nothing to do that my old pc couldn't also do after a quick repair. (new games, maybe VR, etc.) 😂😭

This timing really sucks though, the wait is starting to feel really bad, and the thought of having to wait for the in-between cards... Heck, I've been so out of the loop for so long, I have no clue how long that wait would even be. I'm definitely tempted to just bite the proverbial bullet and hope nothing will be particularly disappointing in the coming year(s). I'd hate to get the 5080 only for a new version of it being released a few months later with all the features I might want but wouldn't have at that point. 😐

NVIDIA developed a totally new cooler and PCB for their cards, but Board partners are just obviously using the 4090s coolers again, since they were designed for 600 Watts already. - So they did not have any additional costs for development, yet their prices will be even higher than NVIDIA's. - It just doesn't make any sense realistically speaking.
I mean, we can see it right here: The 5080, even with this new cooler, is cheaper than the 4080. Yet the 5090 is MUCH more expensive than the 5090. comments.text:
LoL 🤣 wow Nvidia has the card reporting one thing even though it's pulling more power.
Is it just burn off heat?
You know people used to call windows clunky because explorer said it was 90 some percent loaded but nothing on screen that matters to you at that moment, are we regressing in some ways? 
If Nvidia wants to come out swinging why OTHER THAN PRICE did they just come out with the real cards potential and coast because to me that's what it boils down to, a refresh and upsale tactics again, and not even as good as the 40 series offered.
We have had all this technology for sometime now, lines have clearly been drawn same old complaints and the only difference I can really tell is Nvidia is doing this same old song and dance with lower power draw, but is it really? The more people change their bench testing and add more technical dodads to measure individual power draw , the more it seems Nvidia can no longer be trusted to put out a decent card that is at a decent price and a well rounded work horse that can be used to game on as well, so my personal question is when is SLI coming back into mainstream use? Yes I have seen the computers built but they are generally for servers and such, but why can't this be in home computers again?
Seems if you're in the same boat as me you're going to start to want that older technology to be looked at again, because I will pay decent money for 2 cards that can do what I need at less power when figuring the individual card cost but still get the job done with fewest hassle and hoops to jump through. I get why Nvidia wants to charge the most for a single card, they are a business a public business at that, so they have to please their share holders, but is it to much to ask that we should expect a company to hold itself to a higher standard and make a decent card that can game and do some real work or at the very least bring back an updated version of older technology to make this a reality for those that are willing to step back and say this just ain't the future that was promised to us?

comments.text: This generation seems pretty disappointing.  Currently running an EVGA 3080 FTW3 on an 9900k based system I built that originally ran the Chad80 TI (aka EVGA 1080TI FTW3), when the 9900k was the newest CPU out and the then new RTX2080 seemed like a mistake - very similar to this generation too, just instead of RT features it's this frame generation stuff that we miss out on.  For the most part, it still handles everything I throw at it.  and games that support AMD's frame gen feature, like Planet Coaster 2 or other types of non-competetive games where the latency of the "pure fps" is not an issue, it works AMAZING!  Not sure $1000 would be worth an upgrade as realistically I'd probably want to save up and build an entire new system around whatever comes next...  Unless they do announce a 5080 Super/TI at ~1200-1500 that fills this seemingly obvious gap that exists between the 5080 and the 5090..  I'd go in for that and then save up to put that in a newer system.  I'd love to see how these cards compare to 3000 series and 4000 series with the AMD frame generation feature used!

Basically I’m someone who wants a 4080. I’d be upgrading from a 3080ti. The 5080 seems to be the right buy. Waiting 2 gens, like you said I’ll see a tremendous performance uplift. I’m still debating on a 5090 even tho it’s ludicrously expensive and unnecessary for my ultra wide 1440p display. I just want for sure over 60 fps performance with max settings and even rt, without using anything else other than dlss which is amazing. I don’t care for frame gen, maybe only 2x, but that’s not the selling point to me. 

But we’ll see if I can even get either one. If not, I’ll wait until the 5080 super or ti or super ti comes out with hopefully over 20gb vram. That’s what I did when upgrading my 2080 to the 3080ti, which looking back was pretty unnecessary. I’m certainly now not the type to upgrade every gen. This 2 gen’s is minimum to me.

Side note, I understand for 4k why people are so obsessed with the amount of vram. But at 1440p, I’ve barely touched 10gb of usage, so 16gb I think is enough. Not trying to justify nvidia not putting to 20gb, just stating from my experience

comments.text:
jay, you're channel losing relevance because you're focused on the wrong things. Exponential performance gains in a single generation is simply a foolish and unrealistic proposition. Gaming is no longer the only use case for a GPU. You know this...

The real gains are truly portrayed through other metrics about this card: ie. its straight data throughput capability, or its actual architecture. GPUs are nearly a commodity at this point. They are so useful. They are helping people produce more, save time, and make money. And that's why they've become so valuable and expensive. They're bi-purpose tools now, not just play things anymore.  Running local AI models has become a new hobby over night, for instance.

Get ready to see these things(5090s) sell for 2x and 3x MSRP. I mean heck my 2 yo 4090 is worth exactly the same amount i bought it for...just crazy.
comments.author: @plumberman19

comments.text:
Last year I watched lots of videos on monitors as part of my research to get a new one. There were several videos with titles like “my end game monitor”, where people felt that they had found their ‘perfect’ ideal monitor & would not need to upgrade for many years to come.

I’m wondering, as the generational improvements in GPU’s appears to be diminishing, if the 5090 might be an ‘end game’ GPU for many, that they won’t need to upgrade for many years to come. It’s got plenty of vram for example so I can’t see 32GB not being sufficient for many many years to come. All its other specs are really great too like the DDR7, the bus width etc. I suspect that a 6090 & 7090 is going to be hard pushed to improve upon the specs or raw performance that much. They might drop to 3nm fabrication and get a modest freq boost, but I can see most of the effort in the next 2 years going into more Ai as a means of gaining some kind of improvement that marketing can claim the 6090 being so much better than the 5090…& I think most are probably more interested in raw horsepower than some Ai voodoo number.

comments.text:
While the 50 series (except for 5090) may be taking a bit of flak for not being much of an upgrade for gamers, for content creators, it seems to offer a fair bit, but not many are talking about this. 

The new media encoders / decoders have hardware acceleration of H264/h264 4.2.2  codec. This is huge. Up to now only Intel CPU’s have had hardware acceleration of these codecs via Quick Sync, but with the 50 series, the media decoder/encoders are better AND you can get multiple of each of them on the various cards, up to 3 encoders and 2 decoders on the 5090, with them working together to distribute the task. Most consumer cameras record in h264 or h265, it’s when you step up to semi pro video cameras like Blackmagic design etc where they will typically be recording in their RAW format, which would not benefit from the decoders. For folk shooting with cameras like Sony, Canon, Nikon, DJI, they are mostly shooting in H264 or h265 up to 4.2.2 colour sampling.

The advantage of the decoders is that your footage on the timeline will be so much smoother and display faster.
The advantage of the encoders is that when you render out your completed work to h264/h265, the render time will be much shorter than it would other wise be, with 2 encoders just about halving the render time again, & 3 reducing it further. Render times on a modest PC can be crazy long, a 10 min YouTube video can take over an hour old an older PC, but should be down to mere minutes with something like the 5090, and even the 5080 or 70Ti will make a massive difference. 

This media acceleration is particularly great if you are n an AMD platform, or an older Intel one that doesn’t have quick sync.

So just because the 5080 might not be that great an upgrade option for a gamer, it might be a very good one for a content creator.

comments.text:
If AMD has something to call the RX 9080 Series, they would have the opportunity to wreck the RTX 5080, given what we took away from CES about the RX 9070 XT.  But, I can't fault AMD for missing this opportunity, if they missed it.  AMD needed to restrain from producing products like the RX 6500 XT and lower.  If AMD had a GPU, they needed assurance that it would be a revenue generator on the market, not just "make Nvidia drop their prices so I can afford a Geforce card".  I would be assuming Nvidia would push the RTX 5080 to be around the RTX 4090 D in performance (AI embargo stuff), and like an RDNA4 refresh of the RX 7900 XTX would not be good enough against such specs.  But, I feel the reason why AMD has delayed the RX 9070 XT for 2 months is they are now questioning to take this opportunity or not.  If AMD had no hope to catch up, AMD had no real reason to delay 2 months.  The driver maturity statement has been used before and commonly turned out to be nothing.  Pricing issues would be resolved in under a month, easily.  AMD needs to make revenue on the Radeon cards.  The only valid reason left is considering what backlash can happen if AMD announces an RX 9080 XT later in the year after the RX 9070 XT released with the official statement, "No High End RX 9000 series".  AMD needs the 2 months to officially retract that "No High End" statement before the RX 9070 XT launches if AMD determines and commits to the eventual RX 9080, which would mostly be late 2025 release if it had hope.

It is funny how we consider the RX 6000 series cards still relevant today and practically ignore the RTX 30 series in favor of the RTX 40 series.  Is AMD even producing RX 6000 series GPUs?  All the RX 6000 series is stuff still on the shelf, but apparently that stuff is still relevant today.  The RX 7900 XTX will still be relevant against the RTX 5080.  I expect the RTX 5080 will be hitting max stable clock limits in overclocking before hitting a power limit, probably the equivalent max clocks of the RTX 5090 in overclocking.  I am very interested in the RX 9070 XT's overclocks, given the boost clock starts on the doormat of 3GHz's house, where as the RTX 50 series is starting from their car parked out by the sidewalk.

What a disaster.

And I actually disagree with the notion that it is worth it to upgrade to a 50 series for 30 series card users. Thanks to AMDs frame gen, even if it is just 1x, it has uplifted my performance in many, many games to the point where latency is not an issue (thanks to my 3090 already running all games I play well above 60fps on a 5120x1440 resolution with almost all settings at max). I think it would be an actual message if this generation flopped big time and Nvidia has to actually put in some effort once again. I mean, what do people even expect to happen when they always buy these half-assed products? If you keep buying underwhelming products, the developer will keep feeding you underwhelming stuff.

For people that skipped a couple generations like me, or a new builder like you, just think of it as the "4080 2025 model". It's a little better, it costs the same. Buy it if you can afford it, get a 5070 if you can't.

 Don't let people's internet freak outs dissuade you from building a PC. The market is fine. I'm just now having to upgrade my 1660ti because raytracing is mandatory for some stuff now. That's 4 generations old and I'm still exceeding console performance at settings that are absolutely great at 1080p on a smallish monitor. It's expensive but you'll last several console generations on an upper-midrange PC build.

@ lol. The 5090 draws 575W. Let's be generous and compare it the other power hog which is 4090 drawing 450W. Assuming you play for 4 hours per day that would amount to 15kwh more usage during the month and at an avergage US price per kWh of 17 cents that is $2.50 more on your electricity bill each month. 

Keep in mind I've chosen the best possible scenario for the 5090. Assuming you'd upgrade from the 4060 at 115 W and live in Italy with price per kWh being $0.41 and instead of 4 hours per day you play 8 hours per day you'd get monthly price difference of $45.2 which is absolutely massive. That's 545 dollars a year wasted on electricity just for some frames.

comments.text:
@mihairomulus2488  How so? It is based in fact. AMD has for several generations now made it clear that they are fine with not competing. 

They had until recently no one to worry about in the budget market and the technical requirements of that market don't go past "Make screen work". The mid range the requirements are a bit higher but could be easily secured with being moderately cheaper than Nvidia and paper overing any performance numbers with good marketing about "value".
In the high end of the market they can't meet the technical requirements demanded by the market so they rely on outrage and the duopoly to drive anyone pissed off at Nvida to their products and again through marketing "value" and counting on said feelings of outrage to paper over their inferior hardware. Also because of this blind outrage they have learned that these angry customers are fine paying nearly as much as they would for Nvidia's products again performance be damned.

We have seen this play out for almost a decade at this point and such behavior is anti-consumer as it allows Nvidia to do as they please with no market checks and it deceives AMD customers who have been sold on false claims of "value".
